summary: This is an email chain from October 26, 2020, between FBI and NYPD personnel regarding forensic examination of hard drives seized in the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss sending photos of hard drives, coordinating a call to review evidence, and obtaining approval to send a warrant to a judge.

persons.name: Detective
persons.role: NYPD / FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force member
persons.context: Appears as a recipient/participant in the email chain, involved in the investigation and evidence handling.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.role: FBI Special Agent, New York Field Office, Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit
persons.context: Requests photos of hard drives and coordination for a call to discuss the warrant.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Discusses not having taken photos of specific hard drives, mentions poor phone service, and offers to call.

connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Collaborating on forensic examination of hard drives related to the Epstein investigation, with the Special Agent requesting photos and a call.
Both are part of a joint task force (NYPD/FBI) investigating child exploitation and human trafficking, coordinating on evidence and warrant procedures.

events.title: Coordination on hard drive evidence and warrant
events.description: Email exchange regarding sending photos of hard drives (specifically 9 Seagate path 100 hard drives and others), arranging a call to discuss evidence, and obtaining approval to send a warrant to a judge.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: The document references forensic examination of '9 Seagate path 100 hard drives' and other hard drives (IDs 29, 3032) as part of the Epstein investigation.
There is urgency to obtain approval to send a warrant to a judge by the end of the day on October 26, 2020.
The communication involves a joint NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force, indicating ongoing investigative activity years after Epstein's death.
